awd_titl_txt: Interface Structure and Dynamics in Multiferroic Phase Transformations
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The functional properties of emerging electronic ceramics based on structurally and chemically complex metal oxides depend very strongly on the crystal structures of these compounds. A series of recently discovered materials have competing stable phases with different crystallographic structures and can be reproducibly and rapidly transformed between phases. These structural phases differ significantly in their properties; new functionality in electronic and optical devices is enabled by switching between phases. At present, the detailed structural mechanism of these phase transformations, including the motion of the boundaries between phases, is not clear. This project comprises a series of experimental studies designed to probe the dynamics of this phase transformation, to answer key questions about the physical mechanism involved, and ultimately to provide feedback to the design of improved electroceramics.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The single-phase complex oxide bismuth ferrite, a prototypical multiferroic complex oxide, can be reproducibly transformed between structural phases with different symmetries, optical properties, and magnetic structures. Prof. Evans focuses on this model system because bismuth ferrite can be reliably synthesized using epitaxial growth techniques (e.g., ion sputtering, pulsed laser deposition, and chemical vapor deposition) such that it is near a phase boundary where phase transitions can be utilized in electromechanical, optoelectronic, and magnetic devices. Evans's initial results show that bismuth ferrite can be reproducibly transformed between structural phases on timescales as short as tens of nanoseconds, but these studies do not have sufficient time resolution to probe the fundamental timescale of the transformation. Through this project, Evans will (1) determine the short-time dynamics of rhombohedral behaviour (R-like) and tetragonal behaviour (T-like) phase populations in bismuth ferrite using picosecond-scale optical excitation and few-nanosecond-resolution electric field pulses, (2) probe the strain distribution and structure of individual R-like/T-like phase interfaces using X-ray nanobeam diffraction, (3) study the structure and dynamics of individual R-like/T-like interfaces in applied electric fields to determine the difference in dynamics arising from differing interface structures, and (4) explore the extension of these concepts to the interface dynamics in related phase-transforming complex oxides. Evans's work uses emerging synchrotron X-ray nanodiffraction methods, including recent advances in the analysis of diffraction patterns acquired with highly convergent coherent X-ray beams. This project supports the professional preparation of graduate students, participation of undergraduate students in research, targeted outreach through the development and demonstration of educational activities, and the dissemination of materials characterization and X-ray nanobeam diffraction methods to the broader research community.

por.por_cntn:
A longstanding challenge facing researchers in the field of materials science has been to control the properties of electronic materials precisely. A particularly interesting and impactful challenge has been to understand how the properties of a particular material can be changed dynamically in very short times. Said another way the challenge is to discover how the properties can be changed without modifying composition of the material or even changing the temperature. Our project ?Interface Structure and Dynamics in Multiferroic Phase Transformations? addressed the challenge of discovering transformations that can be induced by brief very intense light pulses and probing the ways that these transformations can occur. The project examined optically induced transformations in three related sets of materials: (1) ferroelectric complex oxides, materials that have a long-range electrical polarization built into their structure, (2) multiferroic materials, combining magnetic and ferroelectric order, and (3) a magnetic metal compound exhibiting a structural and magnetic phase transition. The approach to this problem included precise experimental studies and a series of theoretical and computational models that helped to explain the experimental results. The experimental component used advanced synchrotron x-ray nanodiffraction methods, including discoveries in the analysis of diffraction patterns acquired with highly convergent coherent x-ray beams.

These projects were undertaken by a team consisting of researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and collaborators at other universities, national laboratories, and shared facilities for x-ray research.

 

BaTiO3 is a ferroelectric complex oxide in which fascinating physical effects result from the combination of the remnant polarization and the a distortion caused by the polarization. In thin films these two factors combine to drive the formation of intricate domain patterns in which the periodicity, orientation with respect to the crystal lattice, and mesoscopic structure all depend sensitively on the balance between electrostatic and elastic effects.  The absorption of an intense optical pulse leads to a carrier-induced screening of the polarization and to a reconfiguration of the domain pattern. Ultimately, the results provide insight into the mechanism of domain pattern formation and provide the means to manipulate the pattern at short (nanosecond) timescales using optical excitation. The results of the study of the reconfiguration of ferroelectric materials were published in the journal Physical Review Letters in 2021 (Y. Ahn, et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 127, 097402 (2021)).

 

Multiferroic materials are useful in electronic devices and hold out the potential that they can be manipulated and controlled by external parameters such as applied electric field or light pulses. As part of this project the team determined how the multiferroic BiFeO3 can be transformed between two phases, termed R-like and T-like, by manipulating the populations of the phases using picosecond-scale optical excitation and few-ns-resolution electric field pulses. The team further probed the strain distribution and structure of individual R-like/T-like phase interfaces using x-ray nanobeam diffraction. Finally, the team studied structure and dynamics of individual R-like/T-like interfaces in applied electric fields to determine the difference in dynamics arising from differing interface structures. The results of the studies of multiferroic phase transformation were published in the journal Physical Review Letters in 2019 (Y. Ahn, et al. Phys. Rev. Lett. 123, 045703 (2019)).

 

A final discovery as part of this project revealed that heterogeneity had an important role in the in the phase transformation behavior and thermal transport in iron-rhomdium (FeRh) thin films.  FeRh is an intermetallic compound in which there is a simultaneous structural and magnetic phase transformation just above room temperature. The temperature at which the transition is observed is broadened, however, by the heterogeneity of the sample. Optical excitation can be used to transform an FeRh thin film to its high temperature phase. The team discovered that the extent of the transformation from an initial mixed state to the high-temperature state is heterogeneous because of the heterogeneity of the transition temperature.  The resulting high temperature phase also has a heterogeneous temperature distribution and relaxes with different dynamics in different locations. A thermal transport model revealed that in-plane thermal transport, surprisingly, becomes important at key points in the relaxation. The results will have an impact on the design of phase transforming materials through the control of heterogeneity in their properties. The results of the study of the transformation properties of FeRh were published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academic of Sciences in 2022 (Y. Ahn, et al. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 119, e2118597119 (2022)).
